root.tree-val: Biu-Mandara, a subtree of Afro-Asiatic: Gravina 2009
root.pub-comments: Gravina writes that his paper "calls into question the received understanding of the internal classification of the Biu-Mandara branch of Chadic" and "presents evidence in favour of an alternate division of Biu-Mandara into sub-branches" (Gravina 2009: 67).
root.publications: Gravina, Richard. 2009. The internal classification of Chadic Biu-Mandara, Topics in Chadic Linguistics, vol. VI, 67-84. Koln: Rudiger Koppe. ISBN 978-3-89645-526-0

child.pub-comments: Gravina proposes "that these languages do indeed share a common ancestor, though with a degree of uncertainty" (78).

child.tree-val: Biu-Mandara, a subtree of Afro-Asiatic: Gravina 2009
child.pub-comments: "None of the sound changes ascribed to Gidar are found in any of the larger groupings within Biu-Mandara North. As a result, Gidar cannot be placed within any other major group" (Gravina 2009: 81).
child.publications: Gravina, Richard. 2009. The internal classification of Chadic Biu-Mandara, Topics in Chadic Linguistics, vol. VI, 67-84. Koln: Rudiger Koppe. ISBN 978-3-89645-526-0

child.tree-val: Biu-Mandara, a subtree of Afro-Asiatic: Gravina 2009
child.pub-comments: "The Ethnologue (Lewis 2009) lists a further Kotoko language, Jilbe, spoken by around 100 people in Nigeria, but the classification of this language is unknown" (Gravina: 2009 67).
